p.s: The given excerpt shows a complete different side of GatsbysGatsby's character.
His usual ease and confidence is vanished and instead he is nervous and portrayed as inconfident and a shell of a man.
But through the excerpt he finds out something that makes him switch back to his old-self.
The unconfident and nervous characterism of Gatsby in the chapter is firstly portrayed by his description: Gatsby, pale as death (p. 84 l. 14).
The pictural description gives his suffering more importance and depicsdepicts him as even more misreablemiserable.

His worry that the meeting will not go as planned and his helplessness is also mirrowedmirrored in his behaviour as he is: turning sharply as if he were on a wire (p. 84, l. 18) and talking in a muttered voice or little at all (p. 85, l. 3).
To contrast GatsbysGatsby's behaviour furthermore Fitzgerald adds words such as an abortive attempt at a laugh (p. 85, l. 4) or: trembling fingers (p. 85, l. 6).
All those detailed descriptions of GatsbysGatsby's unusual mannerism and characterism are used to contrast it to his usual-self even more.
Outside of this excerpt Gatsby is portrayed as a confident and independantindependent man, who loves to show off his belongings and his wealth.
They're real(p. 47, l. 16).

Although you can tell that the opinion of others about himself matter to him a lot: What's your opinion of me anyhow? (p. 64, ll. 21-22) he is usually more reserved and in a calm distance to everyone: But Gatsby was not there.She couldn't find him from the top of the steps, and he wasn't on the veranda (p. 47, ll. 3-5).
This behaviour is in a big contrast to his behaviour in the given excerpt.
He needs NicksNick's help and acts like a little boy (p. 86, l. 8) who has to cautiously plan his next moves.
He is repeating himself over and over again: This is a terrible mistake [...] a terrible, terrible mistake (p. 86, ll. 1-2) which furthermore stresses his unease and how he is overstretched.

To look into the contrast even more it is interesting to see how he usually acts very carelessnes with his belongings and the things he wants because he wants to be looked up to by everyone: he asked me my name and address - inside of a week I got a package from Crorrier's with a new evening gown in it (p. 45, ll. 18-20).
On the other hand the excerpt shows how destined and desperate he is to win back Daisy: Don't talk so loud (p. 86, l. 7).

The narrative perspective contributes to the awkwardness of the situation as well because it involves a lot of detailed description of Gatsby's nervous behaviour and the tense situation: However, as calmness wasn't and end in itself (p. 85, l. 25).

The little excerpts of Nick's impression of the situation and Gatsby's character further depicdepict a detailed picture of the setting and aura: I had them both on their feet with the desperate suggestion that they help me make a tea (p. 85, ll. 19-20).

Nick's narration makes Gatsby seem even more like a helpless child: You're acting like a little boy, I broke out impatiently (p. 86, l. 8), which is a big contrast as to how he usually describes or talks to him: He smiled understandingly - much more than understandingly.It was one of those rare smiles with a quality of eternal reassurance in it (p. 49, ll. 32-33).
Another contribution to GatsbysGatsby's flustered behaviour is the setting.

The way the rain is very strong and increasingly loud when Gatsby arrives till the moment Nick finds the two of them talking on the sofa, could mirrowmirror GatsbysGatsby's inner feelings and his nervousness.

As soon as Nick describes Gatsby as: But there was a change in Gatsby that was simply confounding.He literally glowed (p. 87, ll. 13-14), it is mentioned that it had stopped raining and the sun came out: that there were twinkle-bells of sunshine in the room (p. 87, ll. 19-20).
This change back to Gatsby's usual behaviour happens suddenly and because of the narrative perspective without the reader knowing.

To add to the change, the description becomes much more positive than the miserable descriptions bevorebefore Nick came back into the house: he smiled like a weather man, like an ecstatic patron of recurrent light (p. 87, ll. 20-21).
GatsbysGatsby's mannerism changes as well, which is visible through him calling Nick old sport again, which is typical of him througoutthroughout the beginning of the novel (p. 87, l. 16).
He gains back his determination and confidence and orders the others around: I want you and Daisy to come over to my house (p. 87, l. 25).
From Nick's narrative perspective the reader does not know what happened in the living room when Nick was outside.

Furthermore this gives Gatsby back his misteriourismmysteriousness that he usually carries around because people only know so little about him and which he lost for a moment by surprisingly oversharing his worries to Nick.
To come to an end it is clearly visible that Gatsby goes through a big change in his behaviour because of his determination to win back Daisy.
His desperation is unusual of him and his nervousness is conveyed through a lot of aspects and ways of Nick's narration.
In addition the change back to GatsbysGatsby's usual character is a big factor as well.
The reader is clueless about what the two of them were talking about and it makes Gatsby even more unknown in a way.
It also makes Gatsby seem very easy to influence and not very strong in his own self.
